title: Score-Based Training for Energy-Based TTS Models
author: Wanli Sun (School of Computer Science, University of Sheffield), Anton Ragni (School of Computer Science, University of Sheffield), ...
relevance_why: The proposed methods like sliced score matching (SSM) and delta loss could be directly applicable in Haohe Liu's work on latent diffusion models and text-to-audio generation. These techniques may facilitate enhanced training strategies for audio tasks.
background: The paper explores training methods for energy-based models (EBMs) in text-to-speech synthesis, aiming to improve how these models generate audio using learned scores.
contribution: This paper introduces Sliced Score Matching (SSM) and a new score-based loss function called delta loss to solve the challenges of training energy-based TTS models, achieving better integration with first-order inference algorithms.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods like Noise Contrastive Estimation (NCE) focus on contrasting samples but have limitations in terms of noisy sample quality and optimization efficiency in text-to-speech applications.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by proposing delta loss that directly optimizes scores towards effective audio synthesis, which can lead to faster and more accurate convergence.

key_innovation: The introduction of delta loss, which encourages scores to provide direct updates towards target speech samples, allows for immediate improvements in inference accuracy.
real_world_impact: This research offers practical methods that could lead to advancements in real-time speech synthesis and audio generation tasks, impacting industries reliant on TTS technologies.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention limitations.

new_terms.Sliced Score Matching (SSM): **Sliced Score Matching** is a technique that optimizes models by comparing their score gradients along random projections, allowing for efficient training without high computational costs.
new_terms.delta loss: **Delta loss** is a new loss function that steers model scores directly towards the difference between noisy and reference samples to facilitate faster convergence.
